pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:2.1: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:4.1: 1. The first training rule on offenses entailing acknowledgment
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:5.1: Venerables, these four rules on offenses entailing acknowledgment come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.2: At that time a nun who was returning from almsround in Sāvatthī saw a monk, and she said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.4: Saying, “Very well, Sister,” he took everything.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.5: But because the time for eating was coming to an end, she was not able to go for alms, and she missed her meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.7: and the following day the same thing happened again.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.11: On the fourth day that nun was walking along a street, trembling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.12: A prominent merchant in a carriage who was coming in the opposite direction saw that nun and said to her,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.14: As she stepped aside, she collapsed right there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.15: The merchant then asked her for forgiveness:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.16: “Forgive me, Venerable, since you fell because of me.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.20: The nun told that merchant what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.21: He then brought her to his house and gave her a meal, and afterwards he grumbled and complained:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.22: “How can the venerable receive food from the hand of a nun?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:6.23: It’s difficult for women to get things.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.1: The monks heard the complaints of that prominent merchant,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.2: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized that monk,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.3: “How can a monk receive food from the hand of a nun?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.4: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.8: “Foolish man, a man and a woman who are not related don’t know what’s appropriate and what’s inappropriate in dealing with each other, what’s right and what’s wrong.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.9: And still you received food from the hand of an unrelated nun.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.10: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:7.11: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:8.1: ‘If a monk personally receives staple or non-staple food from the hand of an unrelated nun who has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he must acknowledge it:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:8.2: “I have done a blameworthy and unsuitable thing which is to be acknowledged. I acknowledge it.”’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:9.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a complete Order through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:10.2: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back seven generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:11.2: she has been given the full ordination by both Orders.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:12.2: a street, a cul-de-sac, a crossroads, a house.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:13.2: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics, the rest is called “non-staple food.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:14.2: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:14.3: If he receives the food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:14.4: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:15.1: If she is unrelated and he perceives her as unrelated, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:15.2: If she is unrelated, but he is unsure of it, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:15.3: If she is unrelated, but he perceives her as related, and he personally receives staple or non-staple food from her hand when she has entered an inhabited area, and then eats it, he commits an offense entailing acknowledgment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.1: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.2: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.3: If he receives staple or non-staple food, with the intention of eating it, from the hand of a nun who is fully ordained only on one side,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.4: he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.5: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.6: If she is related, but he perceives her as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.7: If she is related, but he is unsure if she is, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:16.8: If she is related, and he perceives her as related, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:17.14: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pd1:18.1: The first training rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.
